action.action-desc: Ms. Velázquez(for herself,Mr. Rangel,Mr. Serrano, andMr. Jeffries) introduced the following bill; which was referred to theCommittee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To require large public housing agencies to develop disaster response and relief plans to guide and prepare staff and residents of such agencies, the local community, and Federal, State, and local governments for disasters affecting public housing projects.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Public Housing Disaster Preparedness Act of 2013 .

paragraph.text: The termcovered public housing agencymeans a public housing agency that owns, operates, or assists no less than 500 dwelling units in public housing projects.

The termdisasterhas the same meaning given the termmajor disasterin section 102(2) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act(42 U.S.C. 5122(2))and includes any natural catastrophe (including any hurricane, tornado, storm, high water, wind driven water, tidal wave, tsunami, earthquake, volcanic eruption, landslide, mudslide, snowstorm, or drought), or, regardless of cause, any fire, flood, or explosion, which in the determination of a relevant State or local official causes damage of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant disaster assistance in alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering caused thereby.
The termSecretarymeans the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

section.header: Requirement of disaster response and relief plan

subsection.text: TheSecretaryshall require each covered public housing agency to develop a disaster response and relief plan in accordance with the provisions of this title to provide—

paragraph.text: guidance for—

subparagraph.text: public housing agencies and staff;
residents of dwelling units in public housing;
relevant Federal, State, and local agencies and officials; and
community-based organizations; and

paragraph.text: comprehensive information regarding pre-disaster, disaster impact, and post-disaster policies, standards, procedures, and protocols.

subsection.text: A disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall be included in the annual and 5-year plans required to be submitted undersection 5A of this Act.

paragraph.text: A disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall be submitted to theSecretaryfor approval before implementation of such plan.
TheSecretaryshall have 60 days to respond to each submission made pursuant toparagraph (1).

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall seek input from resident or tenant associations and advocacy groups during the development of the disaster relief plan described insubsection (a).
Nothing in this title prohibits a covered public housing agency from developing and submitting to theSecretarymultiple plans tailored to address specific disasters.

A covered public housing agency shall include in the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title protocols for receiving, analyzing, and disseminating information regarding disasters before, during, and after such disaster.
A covered public housing agency shall—

paragraph.text: provide structure and organization within such agency by establishing a clearly defined chain of command with set responsibilities for each individual or group of individuals involved; and
identify 1 or more individuals or groups of individuals at each agency and each building that is owned, operated, or assisted by each agency that are responsible for—

subparagraph.text: coordinating disaster relief efforts; and

disseminating information regarding emergency protocols under the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title to each resident of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency and other stakeholder groups, including community-based organizations that may provide assistance to such resident following a disaster.

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall disseminate information about the emergency protocols established under the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title to each resident of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency—

paragraph.text: prior to such resident moving into their dwelling unit;
annually; and
if possible, prior to an impending disaster.

subsection.text: Such information disseminated undersubsection (a)shall include—

paragraph.text: information on how to prepare for a disaster;
if necessary, mandatory evacuation protocols;

a list of covered public housing agency and resident rights and responsibilities, as applicable under Federal, State, and local law and regulations, and covered public housing agency rules and emergency protocols before, during, and after a disaster as they relate to—

subparagraph.text: disaster preparedness;
evacuations;
disaster relief;
basic human needs assistance;
utility restoration;
resident relocation;
supportive services;
payment of rent and eligible rent exemptions; and
assessing and repairing physical damage to public housing buildings; and

paragraph.text: any other items that theSecretarymay require through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

subsection.text: The information described undersubsection (b)—

paragraph.text: shall be disseminated by—

subparagraph.text: giving notices and flyers to each resident of a dwelling unit in public housing and posted in high-traffic areas;
having an automated system to contact residents;
posting on the official Web site of the covered public housing agency with links to the appropriate Web pages regarding the impending disaster; and
any other means the Secretary may require through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title; and

paragraph.text: may be disseminated by—

subparagraph.text: phone trees; and
toll-free numbers for residents to call.

subsection.text: The information described under this section shall be accessible to individuals with limited English proficiency.

A covered public housing agency is strongly encouraged to include residents of public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency in the execution of the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title.

section.text: A disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include detailed information on how the authorities plan to allocate and station staff before, during, and after a disaster. The plan should reflect reasonable emergency work hours and ensure staff is on call and prepared for a disaster.

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall maintain a list, updated annually, of the members of each family residing in a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency, and identify the following (as such information is provided by residents):

paragraph.text: The special needs of certain residents because of a disability, physical or mobility impairment, or medical condition.
The units in which residents who are elderly reside.
The units in which residents who have limited English proficiency reside and the primary languages of such residents.

subsection.text: The list described insubsection (a)shall be provided to the individual or individuals identified undersection 503(b)and other relevant staff of the covered public housing agency.

paragraph.text: A covered public housing agency shall analyze the challenges of providing disaster relief assistance with respect to the health and medical needs to certain populations of residents of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency and include such analysis in the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title.
The populations analyzed underparagraph (1)include—

subparagraph.text: residents of a dwelling unit in public housing who—

clause.text: require life-support equipment or have other severe medical conditions;
have a physical or mobility impairment; and

subparagraph.text: other populations of residents identified by the Secretary through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

section.header: Safe evacuation of residents and staff

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall include in the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title information on evacuating residents of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by, and staff of, such agency.
The information required undersubsection (a)shall include the following:

paragraph.text: Detailed protocols regarding evacuating residents and staff of a covered public housing agency safely and orderly.
Transportation options, in addition to public transportation which may be out of service or delayed, for transporting residents and staff to safe locations.
A list of pre-approved public housing agency safe locations for residents and staff.
A list of pre-approved public housing agency fall-back locations for staff to monitor a disaster safely and launch response efforts following the conclusion of such a disaster.
Options for oral and written translation services for residents with limited English proficiency.
Any other information theSecretarymay require through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

section.header: Supporting short- and long-term relocation of residents

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall include in the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title protocols for relocating residents in the event that the unit in which such resident resides becomes uninhabitable.
The protocols described insubsection (a)shall include short-term, long-term, and permanent relocation possibilities.

section.text: A covered public housing agency shall include in the disaster response and relief plan developed under this title protocols for temporarily renting vacant units of public housing to local victims of a disaster who are not residents of public housing.

subsection.text: No covered public housing agency shall begin, continue, or complete an eviction of a resident of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency during the moratorium period defined insubsection (c).
Subsection (a)shall not apply if an eviction of a resident is for—

paragraph.text: a drug-related or violent criminal activity;
a felony charge; or
a sex crime or any violation of Federal or State law related to such resident’s status as a sex offender.

subsection.text: The termmoratorium periodmeans the time period beginning on the date that a disaster is declared by applicable Federal, State, or local officials and ending on the date that the Secretary determines that a covered public housing agency’s disaster relief efforts have concluded.

section.text: A covered public housing agency shall prorate, for each month, the rental amount, and, if applicable, the tenant-paid utility amount of a dwelling unit assisted under this Act for each family residing in a dwelling unit in public housing owned, assisted, or operated by such agency in accordance with the rent abatement policies under the agency’s rules, the property lease executed between the resident and the agency, or any relevant Federal, State, or local laws or regulations.

section.header: Ensuring residents receive basic human needs and assistance

subsection.text: Not later than 24 hours after the conclusion of a disaster, in such manner as the Secretary may require, a covered public housing agency shall provide to each resident of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, operated, or assisted by such agency the following:

paragraph.text: Contact information for Federal, State, local agencies, or other local organizations that can provide supportive services and disaster relief support and assistance, including—

subparagraph.text: potable water;
food;
shelter;
first aid; and
any other support and assistance that the Secretary may identify through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

paragraph.text: Specific information about household and individual assistance available from—

subparagraph.text: theFederal Emergency Management Agency;
any other Federal, State, and local emergency relief agencies; and
local organizations and public housing agency partners.

paragraph.text: Information regarding the personal property damage claims process of a covered public housing agency, including—

subparagraph.text: how to file a claim;
eligibility guidelines for filing a claim;
coverage of the policy; and
the time period to file and process claims.

paragraph.text: A covered public housing agency shall create partnerships to provide basic human needs, additional supportive services, and security before, during, and after the conclusion of a disaster for each resident of a dwelling unit in public housing owned, assisted, or operated by such agency.
A covered public housing agency may establish partnerships with—

subparagraph.text: theFederal Emergency Management Agency;
State and local governments;
local law enforcement;
community-based organizations;
resident or tenant associations;
health care professionals;
other individuals or organizations that provide volunteer services; or
any other entity that theSecretarymay include through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed as to prohibit or restrict any entity from providing disaster relief to any resident of a dwelling unit in public housing.

section.header: Protection and restoration of public housing buildings

subsection.text: The disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include protocols for inspecting, evaluating, and repairing damage to physical assets of a covered public housing agency.

subsection.header: Protocols for protection and restoration of public housing
subsection.text: Such protocols shall include the following:

paragraph.text: Maintaining a list of licensed contractors to assess damage to physical assets and provide short-term repair and restoration efforts.
If possible, executing supportive services contracts in advance of disasters to obtain faster response times.
Deploying contractors immediately following the conclusion of a disaster to assess and repair immediate priorities, including—

subparagraph.text: remediating exigent health and safety hazards, such as mold and mildew removal and pest control; and
other items as described by the Secretary through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

paragraph.text: Not later than 14 days after the conclusion of a disaster, conducting follow-up inspections to determine short- and long-term repair and restoration priorities.
Establishing short-term priorities for the repair and restoration of public housing projects, including—

subparagraph.text: air quality testing to address disaster related health and safety hazards;
continuing to maintain building systems and utilities; and
other items as described by theSecretarythrough regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

paragraph.text: Establishing long-term priorities for the repair and restoration of public housing projects, including—

subparagraph.text: rehabilitating building structures;
repairing and rehabilitating superficial damages to building structures and dwelling units;
mitigating the impact of a disaster that may occur in the future by upgrading or replacing building systems or strengthening the structure of the building; and
other items as described by theSecretarythrough regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

subsection.text: The disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include a detailed list describing the condition and location of emergency supplies and equipment, including—

paragraph.text: electrical generators and the types of public housing building systems they are compatible with;
mobile boilers and the types of public housing building systems they are compatible with;
heaters and fans;
water pumps;
phones, radios, cameras, and televisions (and power sources, if necessary, for these items);
potable water, food, and emergency supply kits;
property vehicles;
first aid kits; and
any other supplies and equipment that the Secretary may describe through regulations prescribed pursuant to this title.

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall check annually to ensure that the supplies and equipment described insubsection (a), or through regulations prescribed pursuant to such subsection, are in working order. Such agency shall immediately replace or repair such supplies and equipment that are not in working order and update the list described insubsection (a).
A public housing agency shall enter into standby contracts for critical equipment, such as pumps, boilers, and generators, in order to expedite the restoration of necessary utilities.

section.text: The disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include—

paragraph.text: how to apply for such resources; and
information regarding the insurance policy of the covered public housing agency and how to file a claim.

section.text: The disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include, and a covered public housing agency shall have available on-site at each public housing project, a step-by-step checklist to implement such plan to be utilized by relevant staff of the agency. Such checklist shall emphasize disaster relief on the property level.

subsection.text: The disaster response and relief plan developed under this title shall include training requirements such as—

paragraph.text: offering no less than 3 events, such as workshops, seminars (held-in person or over the Internet), or conference calls, to provide information to residents on—

subparagraph.text: what to do during a disaster;
covered public housing agency and resident rights and responsibilities during a disaster; and
basic first aid and CPR training; and

paragraph.text: conducting annual evacuation and emergency drills for disasters at public housing projects.

subsection.text: A covered public housing agency shall provide leadership, basic first aid, and CPR training to staff of such agency to prepare such staff to coordinate and assist residents of dwelling units in public housing owned, assisted, or operated by such agency and other individuals in carrying out the pre-disaster, disaster impact, and post-disaster polices and procedures developed pursuant to this title.

A covered public housing agency may provide leadership, basic first aid, and CPR training to residents of dwelling units in public housing owned, assisted, or operated by such agency, in addition to training required to be provided to staff of such agency undersubsection (b), to prepare such residents to coordinate and assist other residents in carrying out the pre-disaster, disaster impact, and post-disaster polices and procedures developed pursuant to this title.

section.text: Following a disaster in which a covered public housing agency implemented its disaster response and relief plan developed under this title, theInspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Developmentshall evaluate such plan and, if necessary, make recommendations for improving such plan not later than 180 days after the conclusion of such disaster.

subsection.text: Section 5A(a)(1) of the United States Housing Act of 1937( 42 U.S.C. 1437c–1(a)(1) )is amended—

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: if applicable, a disaster response and relief plan developed in accordance with title V.

paragraph.text: insubparagraph (A), by strikingand; and
insubparagraph (B), by striking the period and inserting; and.

subsection.text: Section 5A(d) of the United States Housing Act of 1937( 42 U.S.C. 1437c–1(d) )is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignatingparagraph (19)asparagraph (20); and
by inserting afterparagraph (18)the following:

If, applicable, a plan developed by the public housing agency in accordance with title V that provides comprehensive information regarding pre-disaster, disaster impact, and post-disaster policies, standards, procedures, and protocols.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as may be necessary to theSecretaryto carry out this Act.
Any sums appropriated under the authorization contained in this section shall remain available, without fiscal year limitation, until expended.

section.text: A covered public housing agency (as such term is defined in the amendments made undersection 2 of this Act) shall submit the initial disaster plan developed in accordance with the amendments made undersection 2 of this Acton the date that occurs on the later of—

paragraph.text: 270 days after the date of the enactment of this Act; or
the date that the annual plan under section 5A(b) of the United States Housing Act of 1937(42 U.S.C. 1437c–1(b))is required to be submitted to theSecretary of Housing and Urban Development.
